title: Can you get in trouble for writing your child's book report? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: Obviously, you think it is wrong to do this, or you wouldn’t be asking the question. You won’t get into trouble, other than setting a bad example for your child. Rather than learning how to take responsibility for his own learning, he will learn that Mom will do it for him. What kind of lesson is that? Many years ago, we had a parent who came in mad because her son got a “C” on his social studies report. She couldn’t understand why, because she had written it, and Johnny should have gotten an “A.” Unfortunately, Mom wasn’t an “A” student. Instead, Mom taught him that it is okay to turn in work done by someone else with his name on it, and he never got to complete the assignment. As teachers, we work with students to develop their skills and assess their learning. We are not teaching Mom how to write a report or complete an assignment. We want parents to help as part of the learning team, but doing an assignment for their child teaches him nothing, not about the topic, not about researching and organizing thoughts, not about constructing a well-written, informative paper, and most of all, not about the satisfaction of taking on a responsibility and completing it. Why would you want to undermine your child’s education by taking a learning opportunity away from him? He can’t learn by proxy. You had your chance to to get an education. Rather than worry about getting into trouble for doing assignment and risk getting him a poor grade, let him do the learning and have the satisfaction of doing the best job he can.

While you may not get in trouble by the police department or the IRS or even the principal of the school depending on whether or not you get caught or it’s in their handbook explicitly written as punishable by expulsion, you could be in trouble when your child grows up, and doesn’t learn to take initiative. When they don’t learn to take initiative, and when they ultimately become a failure because of one’s enabling them, it could be troublesome to provide ongoing, “economic outpatient care” to them the rest of their lives, because they never knew how to take initiative, and do the work themselves that it takes to be successful in life.

If you aren't planning on writing your child's schoolwork until he graduates, you are setting yourselves up for years of your kid expecting you to bail him out of poor study habits. Even if you dumb down the report, the teacher probably knows what you did, anyway. She knows what your kid sounds like, and she knows what questions to ask to determine whether your kid read the book. Will you, as a parent, suffer school policy consequences? Probably not. But you haven't done your kid a favor.

I need a bit of help with this!! How old is your child? Do parents help children with reports at your child’s school? My first suggestion is that you need to talk to the teacher. I have had parents who helped their child with a book report because of certain learning disabilities. I was very thankful for their help and it was arranged prior to the report being due. I had parents write book reports with their children in pre-school!! The book was read to the child and the child dictated his report to the parent(s) and that worked well. It all depends on the circumstances… AGAIN! Talk to your child’s teacher!!!

NO. But, is your child learning, how to write a book report???? If they need help, do it together, so they learn, how to do it. It’s pretty self centered and uncaring toward your child. to write the book report, just so he gets a good grade. If he/she gets a bad grade, that should be an opportunity, to have some good quality time, with your child.

I’ll come out and say, parents should not be doing their child’s homework. How will the child learn anything? Linda Deming Ratcliff’s comment seems to assume you meant you were helping the child, but that’s not what you asked. Do not do your child’s homework; the trouble you will get in is that your child will not be receiving the education he/she needs and deserves.

It’s trouble that you may not recognize for a while, but it’s not very nice for children to be told that you think they’re incapable of doing their own work. And that’s the message. As I get older, it’s clearer and clearer that the best gift my parents gave me was to say “You’ll figure it out.”

The results, if you are caught, would be: a) your child receives an F on his report, b) your would be called by the teacher to explain why you did it. I do not think they can do much to you but you certainly would be doing more harm to your child than good.

Yes. Why would you do that? If you want a successful child then adult, never do their schoolwork. Sit down WITH them to help or get them a tutor, if they are struggling. It will ONLY get harder for them next time if you do it for them now.
no. your child can get in trouble for not doing the work, but you can’t get in trouble in any way
Oh come on- really- are you asking this question? Get in trouble- are YOU 5? You are the parent- be one. Help you child do the work.
